newsitem.title: GERMANY: SAP stock soars on 1996 earnings surprise.
newsitem.headline: SAP stock soars on 1996 earnings surprise.

text.p: Shares in German software developer SAP AG leapt more than 13 percent in early trading on Friday after the company revealed higher-than-expected results for 1996.

SAP preferred shares, which last year joined the DAX-30 index, were up some 13 percent at 251.90 marks at 0840 GMT, outstripping by far the IBIS DAX index, which was up 0.6 percent at 3,036.76 points.
Its common stock was up 12 percent at 245.20 marks.
"Those were tremendous figures," said a Munich trader. "They gave the market a wonderful boost this morning."
SAP reported a 40 percent rise in its 1996 net profit to 567 million marks and said sales rose 38 percent to 3.72 billion marks, surpassing its own forecast for 30 percent sales growth.
Analysts said the company probably gained on the dollar's recent strength and redoubled sales efforts in the fourth quarter after lowering its forecasts in October.
"The dollar is certainly a key point because their sales are strong overseas," said Peter Thilo Hasler, a Vereinsbank Research analyst in Munich.
"I'm sure they did everything they could in the fourth quarter to increase results, too."
SAP shares had come under heavy pressure earlier this week amid fears that the company would not even meet its own sales forecasts for 1996.
Hasler said he recently cut his recommendation on SAP to below average from market neutral and said he planned to keep that recommendation.
